Thanks for the reply, Gordon. As for SF show, I'm passing on it this time a=
round unless...well, I'm always tempted, you know. Have booked my flight to=
 Japan this fall and this year it'll be two weeks, so with the exchange rat=
e these days...one must be practical with unnecessary trips. Always enjoy t=
he social end of the shows, but nobody is buying anything off tables, so it=
 seems.

While I have your ears...or should I say, eyess...I just put toget=
her a little article for the JSS/US on the theme of "squirrel and grape vin=
es." Surprisingly enough, I found not a lot on the subject on-line and defi=
nitely, not in books. Care to give your opinion of what this theme stands f=
or?????? Sorry, couldn't resist asking!

Regards to the family....Ron
  ---=

  From: robsongo 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups=
.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, July 08, 2009 6:14 PM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy=
] Fw: Sword term meaning...





  Hi Ron,

  The method of attaching menuk=
i to the handle went from the male-female posts
  or iny=F4kon that passed =
through the handle and the nakago fastening the
  menuki to each other to c=
hikara-gane. These iny=F4kon posts continued until
  the late Muromachi per=
iod into the Momoyama period. They are also seen on
  generally high class =
works for the mid to late Edo period; however, they no
  longer went all th=
e way through the tsuka and basically worked as the newer
  chikara-gane do=
. As noted, strength and metal is the literal translation,
  but more accur=
ately I would call them reinforced/strengthened tabs of
  typically copper.=
 On an added note, at least the first three generations of
  the main line =
Goto masters are said to have only used iny=F4kon posts and
  menuki withou=
t them will typically be attributed to Ko-Goto rather than one
  of the mai=
n guys. I expect we will be catching up with many on the list in
  San Fran=
cisco next month. I am certainly looking forward to it.

  Gordon

  _____ =

  Okay, I jumped too soon on this question. I just =
found this described in
  Harry's translation of Nihonto Kozo Vol. 6 in his=
 glossery (page Glossery
  3):

  "Chikaragane: Reinforcement tabs on the b=
ack of the menuki. Chikara means
  strength, Gane is metal." 

  Interestin=
g! 

  Ron
  STL

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Ron Hartmann 
  T=
o: TOKEN ; nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogroups
  <mailto:nihonto%40yahoogrou=
ps.com> .com 
  Sent: Wednesday, July 08, 2009 1:06 PM
  Subject: Sword ter=
m meaning...

  What does the term "chikara gane" mean when refering to the=
 back of menuki?
  On something AY translated for me decades ago he wrote, =
"...in the base,
  chikara gane comes to be used." This is a translation de=
scribing menuki from
  mid-Edo period. (Kinko Mino bori p.109)

  Ron
  STL=
